prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Relative advancement of cases on dockets

para.paratext: The Panel does consider the advancement of the cases to be transferred on the various court dockets. The progress of discovery in the various pending cases is a factor mentioned by the Panel in explaining its choice of transferee court in many cases.[1] This factor may be the most important factor considered by the Panel.[2] The Panel also expresses this factor in terms of advancement toward trial[3] or as a function of the oldest case being pending in the district for a substantially longer period.[4] The Panel sometimes refers to the action or actions in the transferee district as being more “procedurally advanced.”[5] This “procedural advancement” may include establishment of a case management structure, consolidation of actions pending in the court, setting guidelines for discovery, dealing with (or deciding) class certification, deciding key legal issues, or a host of other steps necessary to consider the cases “ready for trial.” Even if the Panel does not transfer the cases to the district in which the actions are most advanced, it will attempt to preserve the progress made in those cases.[6]

The Panel has also expressed that it was transferring actions to the district where the first-filed action was commenced.[7] “First-filed” may also correlate with “most advanced,” so these factors may be blurred together.[8] First-filed status is not a sure thing, however, and the Panel readily transfers actions to other districts.[9]

This is a factor that may be considered by the Panel in conjunction with the factor relating to the venue of the pending actions.[10] The Panel may be more inclined to transfer cases to a district where there are both a large number of actions and they are progressing well toward trial.[11] The combination of these factors may be more powerful than either factor separately. Similarly, this factor is often correlated with the familiarity of the judges.[12] The action that is most advanced toward trial probably is presided over by a judge most familiar with the litigation.[13] These factors are thus often both present. Similarly, where the choice of transferee district is a close one, with two or more available districts being nearly equal, have one district's case be more procedurally advanced may tilt the decision toward that district.[14]

In addition to time pending, the Panel may look to other indicia of “progress” of the actions. In one docket the Panel mentioned the fact that mediation was underway in one district supported transfer there.[15] The Panel has also looked to the progress the transferee judge has made in organizing the cases already pending.[16] The Panel has also pointed to the fact that a judge has already heard expert and factual testimony and held a tutorial on the technical issues in the litigation as favoring transfer to that district.[17]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Smith & Nephew BHR & R3 Hip Implant Products Liability Litigation, 249 F. Supp. 3d 1348 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017); In re Johnson & Johnson Talcum Powder Products Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 220 F. Supp. 3d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re: Roundup Products Liability Litigation, 214 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2013) (noting that “fist-filed” action is also the most advanced); In re Effexor (Venlafaxine Hydrochloride) Products Liability Litigation, 2013 WL 4048494 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Hyundai and Kia Fuel Economy Litigation, 923 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Uponor, Inc. F1807 Plumbing Fittings Products Liability Litigation, 787 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Bank of America Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) Contract Litigation, 746 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2010); In re Activated Carbon-Based Hunting Clothing Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Enterprise Rent-A-Car Wage & Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1325 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Edward H. Okun I.R.S. § 1031 Tax Deferred Exchange Litigation, 609 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Land Rover LR3 Tire Wear Products Liability Litigation, 598 F. Supp. 2d 1384 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Mentor Corp. ObTape Transobturator Sling Products Liability Litigation, 588 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re DirecTech Southwest, Inc., Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) Litigation, 581 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re U.S. Foodservice, Inc., Pricing Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Charlotte Russe, Inc., 505 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Household Goods Movers, 502 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Standard Automotive Corp. Retiree Benefits “ERISA” Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re GMAC Ins. Management Corp. Overtime Pay Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
See, e.g., In re Rembrandt Technologies, LP, Patent Litigation, 493 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2007).
The factor of venue of the pending actions is discussed in § 6:8. The factor relating to the number of actions is also covered in § 6:8.
See, e.g., In re Pet Food Products Liability Litigation, 499 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Republic National-Realty Equities Securities Litigation, 382 F. Supp. 1403, 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
The factor relating to the familiarity of the judges with the litigation is discussed in § 6:14.

See, e.g., In re Ownership of Longoria Bank Deposits Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 913, 916 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Haven Industries, Inc. Securities Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 396 (J.P.M.L. 1976); see also In re Beef Industry Antitrust Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 720, 722 (J.P.M.L. 1976) (actions equally advanced but one judge more familiar with litigation due to proceedings before him).
In re Midland National Life Ins. Co. Annuity Sales Practices Litigation, 484 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2007).

In re Terminix Employment Practices Litigation, 466 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2006). See also In re Gerova Financial Group, Ltd., Securities Litigation, 816 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (mediation as well as substantial progress and majority of actions in district).
See In re AndroGel Products Liability Litigation, 24 F. Supp. 3d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2014).
